title-group.article-title: Mechanical response mechanism and parameter optimization of double-arch tunnels without middle drift during construction

abstract.p: Due to the high construction efficiency and low cost, double-arch tunnels without middle drift has been gradually promoted in engineering in recent years. However, the excavation characteristics of the left and right tunnels are easy to cause structural disturbance and deformation out of control. In particular, the surrounding rock disturbance of the front tunnel caused by the construction of the secondary tunnel often leads to lining cracking and structural instability. Based on the Xinmajie Tunnel project in China, combined with similar model experiments and finite element simulation, the structural mechanical response and failure evolution characteristics during the construction process were systematically studied, and the influence of the excavation of the secondary tunnel on the stress mechanism of the front tunnel was mainly revealed. On this basis, a comparative study was further carried out on the influence of different excavation methods, excavation footage and tunnel face offset parameters about the structural stress. The results show that the deformation of the surrounding rock experiences three stages of “rapid increase‒rapid decrease‒slow increase”, and the disturbance of the secondary tunnel makes the maximum settlement of the front tunnel arch crown increase by 25.56%. The axial force and bending moment of the right arch waist lining of the front tunnel are the largest, and the stress concentration phenomenon is prominent, which is the most unfavorable part of the force. During the loading process, the cracks of the lining structure are concentrated in the weak areas such as arch shoulder, arch crown and inverted arch. In addition, the excavation method of the middle partition wall (first left and then right) and the control of small excavation footage are helpful to weaken the disturbance, and alleviate the stress concentration. The 12 m staggered distance of the left and right tunnel faces is the best in controlling the settlement and plastic zone expansion. It is recommended as an important parameter reference for similar tunnel layout.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: With the rapid advancement of transportation infrastructure construction, large-span tunnel projects under complex geological conditions have emerged in large numbers1,2. Double-arch tunnels have been widely used in the large-span structural system due to its advantages of high space utilization and flexible line selection3,4. However, due to the setting of the middle drift tunnel, traditional double -arch tunnels not only have complicated construction technology and prolonged period, but also easily causes leakage and structural diseases, which seriously affects the service safety and durability of the structure5–7.

To improve the above problems, in recent years, China has explored and applied a new structural form of double-arch tunnels without middle drift in some mountain highway projects. The structure cancels the middle partition wall, and connects the steel arch of the secondary tunnel’s primary support to that of the front tunnel via lapping, enabling both tunnels to share part of the initial support system, and the support of the secondary tunnel is not independent into a ring8–10. This structure effectively simplifies construction procedures, reduces costs, and improves adaptability to complex terrain, showing strong potential for broader application11,12.

However, since this type of tunnel is still in the early stage of engineering practice, the relevant design experience and theoretical basis are limited, and there is a lack of unified design standards and industry guidelines13. Moreover, the characteristics of zero-distance approaching construction make the front tunnel bear the additional load and disturbance induced by the excavation of the secondary tunnel after the lining is stable14. Consequently, the deformation behavior of the surrounding rock and the structural response mechanisms differ significantly from those of conventional double-arch tunnels, making direct application of existing research findings inadequate.

At present, scholars have conducted systematic research on the evolution of surrounding rock pressure, load calculation methods, middle partition wall stability and lining failure of traditional double-arch tunnel15–20. For instance, Sun et al.15 developed a load calculation method for surrounding rock in deep-buried double-arch tunnels based on the Protodyakonov pressure arch theory and staged loading model. Similarly, Min et al.18 revealed the evolution path and failure mode of lining cracks under asymmetric structure conditions by combining model test and numerical analysis. However, these results are mostly aimed at traditional structures with a middle drift, and their applicability to the structure without the middle drift remains to be further verified.

With the advancement of the engineering practice for double-arch tunnel without middle drift, some scholars have begun to explore mechanical behavior and design methodologies. Tang et al.8 and Bi et al.20 established the load calculation model of double-arch tunnel without middle drift based on limit equilibrium and complex variable function theory, respectively. Lu et al.21 utilized FLAC3D to simulate the structural response under different excavation methods. Jiang et al.12 and Wang et al.22 studied the dynamic disturbance characteristics under blasting construction conditions based on LS-DYNA software. These studies have expanded the understanding, but there are still some problems, such as the difficulty of special-shaped contact simulation, the insufficient accuracy of structural node modeling and the limited computational efficiency. Therefore, the reliability of their findings requires further validation through physical experiments.

In contrast, physical model tests have been widely used in the study of deformation and failure mechanism of long-span tunnels, as they can truly reflect the interaction between structure and surrounding rock and avoid the problem of meshing and parameter idealization23–27. However, due to the complex structure of the tunnel, the long period of model making, and the difficulty of building the experimental system28,29systematic physical model studies on this tunnel type are still scarce. Therefore, it is of great significance to improve the design theory and guide the engineering practice to carry out the physical model test research on the double-arch tunnel without middle drift, and to systematically reveal the structural response mechanism and key risk parts in the construction process.

In this context, based on the Xinmajie Tunnel project in Yunnan Province, China, through large-scale indoor model test and finite element numerical simulation method, this paper reveals the structural mechanical response and instability failure characteristics during the construction of the double-arch tunnel without middle drift, and focuses on the analysis of the stress evolution laws of the front tunnel structure during the excavation of the secondary tunnel. On this basis, the mechanical behavior of the front tunnel structure under different excavation methods of the secondary tunnel is discussed. The results fill the research gap in physical model testing of shallow-buried double-arch tunnels without middle drift, and have positive significance for the design and construction of similar tunnel engineering projects.

sec.title: Engineering background
sec.p: The experimental study is based on the Xinmajie Tunnel Project of Nanjing Expressway in Yunnan Province, China. The tunnel has a total length of 0.39 km, a maximum buried depth is 56.9 m. It is a standard construction of two-way four-lane expressway. The tunnel surrounding rock mainly consists of strongly to moderately weathered shale, marl, and sandstone (Fig. 1a). The geological conditions are weak and can be classified as Grade V according to the Chinese design codes for road tunnels27. The front tunnel was excavated using the three-step method with reserved core soil, while the secondary tunnel adopted the two-step method with reserved core soil (Fig. 1b). The tunnel is constructed by the method without middle drift, with both tunnel bores having diameters of 12.87 m and no middle partition wall. The cross-sectional dimension is shown in Fig. 1c, which belongs to a double-arch tunnel without middle drift.

caption.p: The Xinmajie Tunnel project: (a) geological vertical section schematic; (b) sequence of construction; (c) constructional dimension.

sec.p: When the secondary tunnel of the Xinmajie Tunnel was constructed to K52 + 992‒K53 + 047, it was found that the lining of the front tunnel showed signs of progressive failure. Specifically, the concrete manifestation is that the cracks first appear in the middle wall near the side of the secondary tunnel, penetrate along the thickness direction and gradually expand to the side wall of the secondary tunnel. Subsequently, local instability and vault collapse occurred in the primary support of the secondary tunnel, and further induced the overall collapse of the secondary lining of the front tunnel, forming a chain failure. During the failure process, longitudinal penetrating cracks appear synchronously on the surface, and the direction of the cracks is basically consistent with the axial direction of the tunnel. The maximum width is 20 cm (Fig. 2), indicating a global instability of the overlying rock mass. The preliminary analysis indicates that the front tunnel structure experienced significant secondary disturbance during the construction of the secondary tunnel. The middle wall near the side of the secondary tunnel is gradually unstable under the combined action of shear and pressure, ultimately triggering a typical cascading failure process characterized by initial cracking, subsequent collapse, and eventual structural failure. These findings highlight that the construction of double-arch tunnel without middle drift puts forward higher requirements for construction technology and surrounding rock deformation control.

caption.p: Illustration of the cracking and instability process of the tunnel structure.

sec.p: Against this background, it is of great practical significance to carry out similar model tests of to study the mechanical evolution and failure characteristics during tunnel construction, particularly the construction influence of the secondary tunnel excavation on the mechanical characteristics of the structure of the front tunnel, which is of great practical significance to the improvement and promotion of the structural system of the double-arch tunnel without middle drift.

sec.title: Similarity principle

caption.p: Similar simulation conditions.

sec.title: Material preparation
sec.p: The model material is an important part of the similar test. It is not only necessary to consider the mechanical properties of the surrounding rock, but also the raw materials should be as close as possible to the formation parameters of the actual project. The Xinmajie Tunnel is dominated by grade V surrounding rock. Based on previous research results31,32, the similar materials of surrounding rock are mainly barite powder, quartz sand and gypsum. Due to the weak cementation ability between shale and sandstone, a controlled amount of glycerol was added to improve and fine-tune the mechanical behavior of the model material. By preparing standard specimens, the mechanical parameters of similar materials were obtained by direct shear test and uniaxial compression test, and the material ratio was adjusted according to the test results (Fig. 3). Finally, the similar surrounding rock parameters and material ratio of the model were obtained as barite powder: quartz sand: gypsum: water = 1: 3 :0.03 :0.12 :0.01. The specific physical and mechanical parameters of the prototype rock mass and the model similar surrounding rock materials are shown in Table 2.

caption.p: Preparation of similar material for tunnel surrounding rock.
Parameters of prototype and scaled surrounding rock.

sec.p: In the equation, Eeq, Ec, Es, and Eb represent the elastic moduli of the equivalent initial support, shotcrete, steel arch, and reinforcing mesh, respectively; Ieq, Ic, Is, and Ib denote their respective moments of inertia.

caption.p: Structural parameters of prototype and scaled tunnel lining.

tr.th: The front tunnel (the initial support + the secondary lining)

caption.p: Mold and preparation process of the lining similar material.

sec.p: In tunnel model fabrication, the lining structure is often filled in the similar material of tunnel surrounding rock by pre-embedded method36,37. However, this method leads to the deviation between the stress of lining structure and the actual project, especially the inconsistency of the initial stress on the inner and outer surfaces of lining. To overcome this problem, this paper proposes an innovative measure: controllable expansive soil is filled inside the lining to simulate the consistent stress state inside and outside the lining under real conditions, thereby improving the reliability and similarity of the model test.

The selected expansive soil uses montmorillonite and quartz sand as the main raw materials. Based on its characteristics of water expansion, the expansion pressure is controlled by adjusting the ratio. To obtain a reasonable ratio relationship, mechanical performance tests were conducted using a conventional oedometer on samples with varying compositions. The test results show that when the water content of expansive soil is 40% and the mass ratio of montmorillonite to quartz sand is 3: 2, the expansion pressure can reach 19.37 kPa (Fig. 5). This value exhibited a relative error of only 7.07% compared to the numerically estimated initial confining pressure on the outer surface of the lining, thereby satisfying the design requirement for initial stress equilibrium in the model test.

caption.p: Measurement of swelling pressure.

sec.title: Experimental equipment and measurement scheme
sec.p: The experimental model box was designed with a modular structure, and assembled using prefabricated ribbed steel plates and angle steel connected by high-strength bolts. This configuration ensures excellent structural stiffness and enables repeated use in multiple testing scenarios. In this tunnel model test, the adopted geometric similarity ratio was Cl = 40. After scaling down the cross-sectional dimensions of the Xinmajie Tunnel, the individual tunnel dimensions were 32.2 cm (diameter) × 25.7 cm (height). Thus, we determined the overall size of the model box to be 3.6 m (length) × 0.8 m (width) × 2.5 m (height), with an effective internal space of 3.4 m × 0.6 m × 2.5 m. The minimum distance from the tunnel boundary to the model boundary was set to more than twice the tunnel span, effectively eliminating boundary effects on the test results38,39. Transparent tempered glass panels (1.2 m × 1.2 m × 10 mm) were installed on both the front and rear sides (Fig. 6a), which is convenient for observing and recording the deformation and failure evolution of the tunnel rock mass and lining during the test. Additionally, a tunnel excavation contour was pre-defined in the lower section of the model to facilitate tunnel excavation simulations in accordance with experimental requirements.

During the experiment, contact-type monitoring instruments including vibrating wire multi-point displacement meters, micro-strain earth pressure cells, and resistance strain gauges (Fig. 6b) were used to measure tunnel stratum settlement, surrounding rock stress, and deformation parameters of lining structure, respectively. Displacement gauges were installed within the surrounding rock on both sides of the tunnel, with vertical distances of 10 cm, 30 cm, and 70 cm from the tunnel crown, respectively, to capture the settlement response characteristics of the strata at varying depths. Earth pressure cells were installed at key structural locations along the tunnel lining on both sides, including the arch crown, arch shoulder, side wall, arch foot, and inverted arch, to monitor variations in the confining pressure acting on the structure. Resistance strain gauges were mainly arranged in the typical parts of the front tunnel lining, including the arch crown, arch shoulder, side wall, and inverted arch. They are arranged along the longitudinal direction of the tunnel with a spacing of 15 cm, which is used to record the strain evolution laws of various structural sections during loading process. The specific layout of the measuring points is shown in Fig. 6c.

caption.p: Tunnel model device and measurement point layout: (a) model box; (b) testing components; (c) measurement point layout.

sec.title: Model construction and testing procedure
sec.p: During the tunnel model test, the construction process was carried out in the following sequential steps, as illustrated in Fig. 7.

list-item.p: Preparation and layered placement of similar materials. The surrounding rock simulation material was prepared according to the predefined mix ratio scheme and placed into the model box from bottom to top in successive layers. Each layer was compacted to a controlled thickness of 10 cm using a mini hand tamper until the required standard compaction density was achieved. This procedure ensured material uniformity and mechanical consistency, thereby providing stable boundary conditions for subsequent structural response simulations.

Installation of lining structure. After the surrounding rock simulation material was filled to the predetermined height, the prefabricated lining structure was hoisted and positioned at the designated location. To prevent potential damage to the bottom of the lining structure during the installation process, a foam board was placed underneath as a cushion. Subsequently, expansive soil was filled inside the lining while surrounding rock simulation material was continuously placed around it. This simultaneous operation ensured a balanced stress state on both the inner and outer sides of the lining, thereby avoiding initial stress imbalance that could compromise the accuracy of the test results.

Monitoring equipment installation and initial consolidation. In the process of model filling, earth pressure cells and multipoint displacement gauges were embedded at the designated measurement locations in accordance with the pre-established layout. Care was taken to ensure logical arrangement, clear sensor labeling, and smooth cable routing, thereby facilitating efficient data acquisition and subsequent analysis. After all the materials were filled and the equipment was installed, the model was left undisturbed for 48 h to allow sufficient consolidation under its own weight. This process established a relatively stable initial stress condition, providing realistic and reliable initial conditions for subsequent excavation and loading simulations.

caption.p: Preparation process of the tunnel model test.

sec.p: During the construction of the Xinmajie Tunnel, the front tunnel was excavated using a three-bench reserved core soil method, while the secondary tunnel adopted a two-bench reserved core soil method. Excavation of the secondary tunnel was initiated only after the completion of the pilot tunnel. To truly reflect the actual construction process and mechanical response of the tunnel, the same excavation sequence is adopted in the model test, and the specific process is shown in Fig. 8. In the experiment, the excavation advance per step was set at 5 cm. The entire tunnel excavation process was completed in 24 sequential cycles to simulate the actual construction pace and the progressive evolution of disturbance in the surrounding rock–structure system.

caption.p: Excavation process of the tunnel model test.

sec.p: In geomechanical model tests, the stepwise loading method has been widely applied to study the evolution of mechanical behavior in tunnels and surrounding rock, as well as the failure mechanism of lining structures33,40. Therefore, after completing the excavation of the whole tunnel model and confirming that the settlement had stabilized, the loading scheme was applied to study the structural response, focusing on the failure characteristics and mechanism evolution of the weak parts of the lining. The loading test adopts the equal incremental loading method, the loading step is 20 kPa, and the maximum loading value is 0.8 MPa, which ensures that the whole process data of structural response can be obtained within the controllable load range, and provides experimental data support for subsequent analysis.

sec.title: Settlement evolution of the surrounding rock
sec.p: Figure 9 shows the displacement evolution of the surrounding rock at arch crown of the left and right tunnels during the simulated excavation process of the double-arch tunnel without middle drift tunnel. It is worth noting that, due to the pre-embedded installation of the lining structure in the model, the surrounding rock’s freedom to deform was constrained, resulting in overall displacement values that were relatively smaller than those observed in actual conditions.

Before the excavation of the front tunnel to the monitoring section, the displacement of the arch crown rock mass increases rapidly, and the settlement of point F1 is the largest, reaching 0.037 mm, indicating that the early excavation has a significant effect on the stress release of the surrounding rock. Meanwhile, the secondary tunnel, which had not yet been excavated, experienced minor settlement at the crown due to disturbance from the pilot tunnel excavation, with a maximum value of 0.009 mm. This suggests that the initial excavation-induced disturbance exhibited a certain degree of spatial propagation. Meanwhile, the secondary tunnel, which had not yet been excavated, experienced minor settlement at the crown due to disturbance from the front tunnel excavation, with a maximum value of 0.009 mm. This suggests that the initial excavation-induced disturbance exhibited a certain degree of spatial propagation. As the excavation face passes through, the arch crown deformation rate of the front tunnel gradually decreased. After the completion of the connection, the final maximum settlement at the arch crown reached 0.067 mm. During the excavation of the secondary tunnel, the deformation trend of the surrounding rock remained generally consistent with that of the front tunnel, but exhibited greater displacement magnitudes. In particular, settlement at point S3 increased progressively and peaked at 0.111 mm during breakthrough, indicating a pronounced late-stage ground deformation response. At this time, the maximum deformation value of the F3 point at the corresponding position of the front tunnel is 0.090 mm, which is significantly higher than the deformation value of its previous penetration. Analysis reveals that secondary tunnel excavation induced a substantial secondary disturbance to the front tunnel, contributing 25.56% of the total settlement at point F3. In contrast, only 1.80% of the total settlement at point S3 could be attributed to disturbance from the front tunnel. These findings demonstrate that, during the construction of the double-arch tunnel without middle drift tunnel, the secondary tunnel exerts a significant secondary disturbance effect on the arch crown of the front tunnel, whereas the reverse influence is relatively negligible.

caption.p: Deformation curve of the tunnel arch crown.

sec.title: Variation of surrounding rock pressure
sec.p: Figure 10 shows the evolution of surrounding rock pressure behind the lining of both the front and secondary tunnels with the excavation process. The y-axis denotes the magnitude of pressure change at each monitoring point relative to its initial state, thereby illustrating the mechanical response and evolution characteristics of the surrounding rock under excavation-induced disturbance.

Before the excavation of the front tunnel to the monitoring section (Fig. 10a), the surrounding rock pressures at all monitoring points exhibited an overall increasing trend, with notable amplification at the crown and arch shoulder locations (F1 and F8). This behavior reflects the influence of a “wedging effect” caused by excavation face disturbance under weak geological conditions, which acted in advance on the forward rock mass and led to the formation of a localized stress concentration zone. As the tunnel face approached the monitoring section, the surrounding rock pressure decreases rapidly, and enters the stage of stress release and relaxation. The local plastic zone expands significantly, and the surrounding rock is in an unstable transition state. Subsequently, the surrounding rock pressure gradually stabilized and began to rise slowly, indicating the progressive establishment of a new load-bearing path in the crown area, and the development of an arching effect. During the construction of the secondary tunnel, the zero-clearance layout led to a clear secondary disturbance in the front tunnel’s surrounding rock. A significant pressure increase was observed at the arch shoulder and inverted arch regions (F7 and F8), suggesting that the disturbance was transmitted through the structural connection zones, resulting in reverse loading and a diminished structural safety reserve. The surrounding rock pressure in the secondary tunnel shows a three-stage characteristic of “rise‒sudden drop‒stabilization (Fig. 10b). In the early phase, the surrounding rock was located within the residual stress field induced by the front tunnel’s disturbance. The excavation further breaks the original stress balance, especially in the inverted arch and arch shoulder (S5–S8), where significant unloading and structural weakening were observed, reflecting the sensitive area of surrounding rock failure. Furthermore, during the construction of the secondary tunnel, the stress of the side wall (F3), arch foot (F4), inverted arch (F5, F7) and arch shoulder (Z8) on the side of the secondary tunnel all increased to varying degrees. These observations further validate the asymmetric and strongly coupled disturbance characteristics inherent to double-arch tunnels without middle drift.

caption.p: Evolution of surrounding rock pressure during excavation: (a) the front tunnel; (b) the secondary tunnel.

sec.title: Structural internal force distribution characteristics
sec.p: Figures 9 and 10 show that in the double-arch tunnel without middle drift, the excavation of the secondary tunnel significantly disturbs the surrounding rock stress field of the front tunnel and induces the asymmetric evolution of the internal force within the lining structure. Due to the sequential excavation of the twin tunnels, the disturbance exhibited distinct spatial and temporal asymmetry. Therefore, analyzing the internal force variation in the front tunnel lining during the secondary tunnel excavation is crucial for revealing the underlying structural stress mechanisms. The corresponding calculation results are presented in Fig. 11. After the front tunnel is penetrated, the axial force and bending moment of the lining show the distribution characteristics of “large in the upper and small in the lower, large in the right and small in the left”. The maximum axial force and bending moment are concentrated on the right wall near the side of the secondary tunnel, which are 12 kN and 2.1 kN m, respectively, which are 21.67% and 9.52% higher than those on the left side. With the advance of the secondary tunnel excavation, With the advance of the secondary tunnel excavation. When the secondary tunnel is constructed to 1/3 section, the axial force difference between the two sidewalls reached up to 58.47%. The bending moment followed a similar trend, with the right sidewall exhibiting a peak positive bending moment of 3.5 kN m, indicating significant tensile stress on the inner surface and an elevated risk of cracking. This suggests that the disturbance induced by the secondary tunnel was transmitted to the front tunnel via the structural connection region, establishing an asymmetric stress mechanism characterized by a “bias–transfer–feedback” sequence. Since the secondary lining of the secondary tunnel had not yet been installed, the structural stiffness remained insufficient, causing part of the confining pressure to be transmitted through the surrounding rock to the right side of the front tunnel lining, thereby creating a zone of stress concentration. In particular, the weak stiffness parts such as the side wall and the arch waist are prone to “tensile–shear” failure under the interaction of axial force and bending moment. This process, when combined with reverse-transmitted disturbance, may further induce a secondary collapse in the front tunnel structure.

caption.p: Internal force distribution in the primary support of the front tunnel.

sec.title: Mechanism of structure
sec.p: Different from traditional double-arch tunnels, double-arch tunnels without middle drift structure cancels the key bearing member of the middle partition wall. The construction characteristics of zero-spacing arrangement in this structure enable the boundary constraints of the structure to be weakened, and the disturbance propagation of the surrounding rock to be more direct during the construction process. This significantly aggravates the asymmetric stress evolution characteristics of the structure-surrounding rock system. The force evolution is shown in Fig. 12.

In the excavation stage of the front tunnel, the stress mode is similar to that of conventional single-hole tunnels. The surrounding rock gradually forms a pressure arch, and the load is transmitted to the side wall through the arch foot. The whole is in a small eccentric pressure state, and the structural stability is well. With the excavation of the secondary tunnel, the stress path of the structure-surrounding rock system is reconstructed. Due to the lack of partition structure, the surrounding rock load on the secondary tunnel can be transmitted to the right side of the front tunnel through the primary support and the surrounding rock between the two arches, resulting in a significant increase in the additional load in this area. At the same time, the disturbance destroys the “gripping effect” of the original rock mass, weakens the structural constraints on the right side of the front tunnel, and the force gradually evolves from a small eccentricity to a large eccentricity, and the asymmetry is significantly enhanced. The stress of the components such as the arch shoulder, arch crown and side wall of the front tunnel is uneven, the local bending moment is increased, and the risks of inner tension and outer collapse are easy to occur. Especially in the stage where the secondary lining has not been applied to the secondary tunnel, the structural stiffness is insufficient, which is more likely to cause the load to shift to the front tunnel, and form unfavorable working conditions. The test results further show that the internal force of the lining on the right side of the front tunnel (such as arch waist and side wall) increases significantly, which reflects that the disturbance has clear directionality, and the right side is the first to enter the high stress state.

caption.p: Construction stress state.

sec.title: Cracking and failure analysis of structure under loading condition
Variation of surrounding rock pressure
sec.p: Figure 13 shows the evolution of the surrounding rock pressure behind the tunnel lining during the loading process. The whole process can be divided into three stages: initial plateau‒rapid rise‒slow growth, which reflects that the structure—surrounding rock system changes from elastic response to stress concentration under additional load, ultimately leading to stress redistribution driven by localized structural failure.

During the initial loading stage (0‒0.3 MPa), the pressure at monitoring points in the both tunnels increased slowly, the structure is in a state of compaction and bonding, and the system response is relatively stable. After entering the middle stage of loading, the pressure of surrounding rock rises rapidly, and the response trend of both tunnels gradually diverges: the stress on both sides of the inverted arch (F5, F7) and the right shoulder (F8) of the front tunnel increases significantly, with a maximum value of 0.45 MPa, forming a concentrated area. Although the side of the secondary tunnel near the front tunnel also showed a significant increase, the growth rate and peak value are lower than those in the front tunnel. Some monitoring points showed a plateau later. This indicates an asymmetric response between the two tunnels. The fundamental cause of this difference lies in the initial stress asymmetry induced by the excavation sequence. The surrounding rock on the right side of the front tunnel is subjected to additional disturbance during the excavation of the secondary tunnel, forming a bias accumulation zone. As a follow-up load, the surcharge load further amplifies this initial bias pattern, resulting in a particularly significant stress concentration effect in the right arch waist and inverted arch region of the front tunnel. Meanwhile, double-arch tunnels without middle drift structural characteristics make the arch waist lap area the main load coupling path between the left and right tunnels, and the area bears a greater vertical load superposition effect. In the late stage of loading (> 0.62 MPa), the pressure at most monitoring points increases more slowly or tends to level off. This may result from local cracking of the structure or changes in the contact condition between the surrounding rock and the lining, which cause stress release or a shift in the load transfer path. It is worth noting that the front tunnel measuring points (F7, F8) near the side of the secondary tunnel still continue to rise, indicating that the region has not yet formed an effective crack release mechanism, and the structural deformation is still developing continuously, with a higher risk of instability.

caption.p: The variation curve of surrounding rock pressure: (a) the front tunnel; (b) the secondary tunnel.

sec.title: Distribution characteristics of the structural internal force
sec.p: Figure 14 shows the internal force distribution laws of the primary support of the double-arch tunnel without middle drift under additional load, and reveals the stress response mechanism and spatial distribution characteristics of the structure with the change of loading grade. The internal force of the structure shows obvious non-uniform distribution characteristics. Especially in the arch shoulder and inverted arch area on the side of the secondary tunnel adjacent to the front tunnel, the axial force and bending moment increase synchronously, indicating that the area gradually evolves into the core part of load transfer.

In the early stage of loading (< 0.2 MPa), the structure remains in the elastic phase. Stress at all monitoring points is relatively uniform and changes slightly, and there is no significant stress concentration. With the gradual increase of load (0.2–0.5 MPa), tress at the arch shoulders and inverts arch on the adjacent sides of both tunnels grows rapidly. These areas enter the nonlinear response stage first, reflecting that the stress concentration develops based on the initial disturbance. When the additional load increases to 0.6 MPa, the internal force non-uniformity is further aggravated. Taking the front tunnel as an example, the axial forces of the right arch shoulder and inverted arch are increased to 115.02 kN and 102.43 kN, respectively, which are significantly higher than the initial growth rate. The corresponding bending moments increase to − 10.28 kN m and − 14.08 kN m, indicating a typical state of “high axial compression–large bending moment” interaction, and the local strength reserve of the structure is significantly reduced. In contrast, the axial force and bending moment corresponding to the left arch shoulder are reduced to 67.75 kN and − 7.26 kN m, respectively, with a decrease of 29.17% and 40.83%, showing a significant asymmetric stress distribution. This shows that under the boundary condition of the without middle drift, the additional load not only leads to the redistribution of the overall stress of the structure, but also promotes the connection area between the two arches to become the main control force path, which significantly amplifies the initial bias effect caused by the construction disturbance.

caption.p: Distribution curve of internal force section of primary support under additional load.

sec.title: Failure characteristics of lining
sec.p: Figure 15 shows the cracking and development process of lining structure after loading, and further reveals the progressive failure mechanism of double-arch tunnels without middle drift under additional load. On the whole, the cracks initially originate from the stress concentration area, and then gradually expand to other weak parts of the structure with the increase of load level. The failure process is highly consistent with the evolution of structural stress.

At the initial stage of loading, the whole structure is in the elastic stage, but the crack (# 1) first appears in the right arch shoulder of the front tunnel, which indicates that the area has become the initial failure trigger point under the action of asymmetric bias. As the load increases (0.2−0.5 MPa), the internal stress level of the structure increases rapidly, and the cracks gradually expand to the arch shoulder, arch crown and inverted arch of the secondary tunnel (# 2−6). The local stress level of the structure is significantly improved. Under the influence of vertical load, the “elliptical” deformation trend of tunnel section is obvious, which reflects the transformation of the structure from linear elasticity to nonlinear response stage. When the load continues to increase (0.6−0.8 MPa), the cracks in the inverted arch area penetrate and develop along the direction of the arch foot and the side wall (# 7, # 8), forming a typical shear-bending composite effect to induce failure, indicating that the area has entered the local instability stage.

caption.p: Crack evolution of tunnel lining.

sec.p: On the whole, the cracks gradually expand along the path of “arch shoulder→arch crown→inverted arch→arch foot”, which reflects the reconstruction of the structural stress path and the transfer process of the main control area under the action of bias coupling. The evolution trend is consistent with the distribution characteristics of surrounding rock pressure and internal force, which further verifies the reliability of the test results.

sec.title: Establishment of the numerical model
sec.p: Based on the aforementioned tunnel physical model test, a three-dimensional numerical model of double-arch tunnels without a middle drift was established using the finite element software ABAQUS (Advanced Simulation for Engineering and Sciences, Version 2022, https://www.3ds.com/products/simulia), with the objective of validating the experimental results and further optimizing the construction parameters. Therefore, the dimensions and parameters of the numerical model were determined according to the physical model test. Considering the geometric similarity ratio of the physical model (Cl = 40), the numerical model dimensions were scaled to 144 m (length) × 32 m (width) × 100 m (height), which is 40 times the physical model size (Fig. 16). Similarly, the minimum distance from the tunnel contour to the numerical model boundaries was kept greater than twice the tunnel span, ensuring the effective elimination of boundary effects38,39,42. Additionally, boundary conditions were applied as follows: normal constraints were imposed on the front, rear, and lateral boundaries of the surrounding rock mass; vertical constraints were applied to the bottom boundary; and the top boundary was set as free, to realistically simulate the deformation of the surrounding rock during tunnel excavation and loading.

In addition, in the model test, the similar materials of surrounding rock are mainly composed of barite powder, quartz sand, and gypsum, which can be approximated as homogeneous without obvious random cracks or interfaces. Furthermore, the pre-embedded lining structure during the test effectively limits the deformation of the surrounding rock during the subsequent excavation and loading stages. Therefore, the Mohr–Coulomb strength criterion is selected to characterize the shear failure behavior of the tunnels3,7,16,39,41and the lining structure is modeled as a linear elastic material. The detailed computational parameters are shown in Table 4.

caption.p: Tunnel numerical calculation model.
Calculation parameters of the tunnel numerical model.

sec.title: Comparison of the numerical and the experimental results
sec.p: Taking the vertical displacement of arch crown surrounding rock during the tunnel excavation as an example, the numerical results are compared with the model test evolution process, as shown in Fig. 17. It can be seen that the overall trend of the tunnel surrounding rock settlement is consistent with the physical model test results (Fig. 9), both of which are characterized by the deformation stage of “slow‒rapid‒slow”. The maximum settlement occurs at the point S3, located at the arch crown of the secondary tunnel, with a value of 10.05 mm. As the tunnel face of the secondary tunnel approaches the monitoring section, the settlement rates of the surrounding rock in both tunnels increase simultaneously. After the tunnel face passes the section, the settlement rate gradually slows down, and the surrounding rock deformation tends to stabilize. It is worth noting that the surrounding rock at the point F3 in the front tunnel undergoes significant additional settlement due to the excavation of the secondary tunnel. The increase accounts for approximately 28.27% of the displacement observed after the initial excavation of the front tunnel, which is close to the 25.56% observed in the physical model test. The result clearly reflects the biased loading disturbance effect induced by the secondary tunnel excavation. It significantly influences the secondary deformation of the surrounding rock near the existing structure, and confirms the effectiveness and reliability of the simulation scheme.

caption.p: Numerical results of vertical displacement at the tunnel crown in the surrounding rock.

sec.title: Construction parameters optimization analysis
sec.p: The aforementioned test results indicate that the excavation of the secondary tunnel plays a critical role in the overall stability of double-arch tunnels without middle drift. It imposes more stringent requirements on deformation control of the pilot tunnel structure. Therefore, it is of great engineering significance to systematically analyze the mechanical response law of the structure-surrounding rock system under the construction disturbance of the secondary tunnel to optimize the construction organization parameters.

On this basis, a sensitivity analysis of construction parameters is conducted using the 3D numerical model established in the previous section. The analysis focuses on key control parameters, including different excavation methods of the secondary tunnel, single-step advance length, and the staggered arrangement of tunnel face on the structural stress state and surrounding rock deformation field. By comparing and analyzing the internal force of tunnel structure, displacement of surrounding rock, and response characteristics of key nodes under different working conditions, quantifiable design optimization suggestions are provided for engineering application.

sec.title: Simulated conditions
sec.p: To systematically evaluate the influence of critical parameters on the structural stability of the front tunnel during the construction of the secondary tunnel, 11 excavation scenarios were modeled, involving variations in excavation method, advance length, and face offset, as summarized in Table 5.

caption.p: Different construction parameters.

tr.td: Middle wall method (left first and right later)
Middle wall method (right first and left later)
Left and right tunnel face stagger distance (m)

sec.title: Results analysis of different excavation methods

caption.p: Vertical deformation of the tunnel surrounding rock.

sec.p: Figure 18 shows the vertical displacement contours of the surrounding rock under different excavation methods for double-arch tunnels without middle drift. The maximum settlement values at the tunnel arch crown under the four working conditions are − 12.7 mm, − 12.62 mm, − 11.04 mm, and − 11.94 mm, respectively. Compared with the original scheme (Case 1), the optimized excavation methods reduce the arch crown settlement by 0.63%, 13.07%, and 5.98%, respectively. In addition, a comparison of inverted arch heave shows that Cases 3 and 4 achieve reductions of 8.23% and 8.56%, respectively. These results indicate that the staggered excavation scheme based on the middle wall method (left first and then right, Case 3) offers the most effective control over surrounding rock deformation.

list-item.p: Internal forces of the secondary lining in the front tunnel.

sec.p: The internal force distribution characteristics of the secondary lining in the front tunnel under four different excavation methods are shown in Fig. 19. The results show that the side wall of the front tunnel is consistently exhibits the peak internal forces, and the maximum axial forces in each working condition are 853 kN, 855 kN, 629 kN and 692 kN, respectively. The maximum bending moments also occur in this area, displaying a similar distribution pattern. Compared with the original condition, the maximum axial force of the side wall in Cases 2 to 4 is reduced by 0.23%, 26.26%, and 18.87%, respectively. These results indicate that certain optimized excavation methods effectively alleviate the eccentric loading effect and reduce the concentration of internal forces. In addition, adopting the middle wall method and prioritizing the excavation of the rock mass adjacent to the front tunnel significantly alleviates the coupled stress in the haunch-lap zone and enhances the structural stress uniformity. This method proves to be the most effective scheme among the tested cases in controlling the internal force response.

caption.p: Lining internal force distribution.

sec.p: Figure 20 shows the spatial distribution characteristics of the plastic zone in the surrounding rock under different working conditions. It can be observed that although the plastic zones are generally located in similar regions across all cases, all of which are concentrated in the lap area of arch waist and its surrounding areas, there are significant differences in their scale and shape. The original condition (Case 1) induces the largest extent of the plastic zone, indicating that under full-face excavation, despite the smaller advance per round, the frequent disturbances cumulatively weaken the stability of the surrounding rock. This effect is particularly pronounced at the junction between the left and right tunnels, where an extensive plastic evolution is observed. In contrast, the CD method with sequential excavation significantly reduces the disturbance to the surrounding rock. Among them, the first excavation near the side of the front tunnel (Condition 3) is the most prominent in reducing the plastic expansion in the arch waist and inverted wall area, resulting in the smallest plastic zone. This effectively suppresses the unstable evolution at the structure–rock interface. Therefore, from the perspective of controlling plastic damage in the surrounding rock, the “middle wall method (left first and right later)” proves to be the most favorable excavation approach for the secondary tunnel.

caption.p: Plastic zone contour maps of surrounding rock.

sec.title: Results analysis of different excavation footage
sec.p: Figure 21 shows the vertical deformation contours of the surrounding rock under different single-step excavation lengths when the secondary tunnel is excavated using the CD method (left first and right later). The results show that with the increase in excavation length, the magnitude of arch crown settlement and inverted arch heave increases significantly, and the disturbance to the structure becomes more intense. Specifically, the maximum crown settlements are 1.27 m, 1.34 m, and 3.16 m respectively, which is 5.22% and 148.82% higher than that of 2 m footage. The uplift of the inverted arch is 1.03 m, 1.01 m and 1.54 m, respectively, changing by − 1.94% and 49.51%, respectively. This shows that when the footage increases to 4 m, the structural response has entered the nonlinear stage, and the deformation of surrounding rock expands sharply. From the perspective of spatial distribution characteristics, the vertical deformation of the surrounding rock shows an approximately symmetric pattern between the left and right tunnels under 2 m and 3 m excavation lengths, suggesting that the disturbance remains controllable. However, when the excavation length increases to 4 m, settlement becomes significantly concentrated on the secondary tunnel side and far exceeds that on the front tunnel side. The structural disturbance exhibits strong asymmetry, indicating a pronounced bias-induced effect.

caption.p: Vertical deformation contours of surrounding rock.

list-item.p: Internal forces of the secondary lining in the front tunnel.

sec.p: Figure 22 shows the internal force distribution characteristics of the secondary lining structure in the front tunnel under different excavation footage. The results show that as the single-step excavation length increases, both axial force and bending moment in the lining increase significantly, especially the stress concentration trend in the right hance area is the most obvious, and the internal force distribution of the structure shows asymmetric characteristics. Specifically, the maximum axial forces of the lining structure under the three working conditions are 618 kN, 859 kN, and 1285 kN, respectively, which are 39.00% and 49.59% higher than the previous working conditions. The maximum bending moments were − 144 kN m, − 285 kN m, and − 551 kN m, with an increase of 97.92% and 93.33%, respectively. Further comparison shows that when the footage is increased to 4 m, the maximum axial force and bending moment of the lining structure are increased by 107.93% and 282.64% respectively compared with the 2 m working condition, and the structural response shows a sharp growth trend. This shows that when the excavation step exceeds a certain threshold, structural response transitions from a linear growth stage to a nonlinear deformation stage. Significant stress concentration and redistribution occur at structural boundaries, indicating that the overall bearing capacity approaches its limit state.

caption.p: Lining internal force distribution.

sec.p: Figure 23 shows the distribution characteristics of plastic zone in surrounding rock under different footage conditions. When the footage is 2 m and 3 m, the plastic zones are mainly distributed in the arch waist and the arch shoulder and inverted arch near the lap side of the structure. The maximum equivalent plastic strains are 2.07e−2 and 2.91e−2, respectively, indicating that the disturbance to the surrounding rock remains within a controllable range. However, when the excavation length increases to 4 m, the plastic zones expand significantly and begin to concentrate around the side wall of the secondary tunnel and the lap joint area. The maximum equivalent strain increases sharply to 6.34e−2, reflecting enhanced non-uniform stress release and pronounced local yielding of the surrounding rock. This evolution trend is consistent with the vertical deformation patterns of the surrounding rock (Fig. 21) and the amplified internal forces of the structure (Fig. 22), confirming that excessive excavation length can trigger non-uniform plastic failure in the surrounding rock and significantly increase the instability risk of the structure–rock system.

In summary, an excessively large single excavation length weakens the progressive nature of stress release in the surrounding rock. This leads to intensified non-uniform deformation of the structure–rock system, increasing the risk of local instability and complicating deformation control. Therefore, it is recommended that the single excavation length be limited to no more than 3 m to achieve a reasonable balance between deformation control and construction efficiency.

caption.p: Plastic zone contour maps of surrounding rock.

sec.title: Effect of longitudinal excavation face offset between twin tunnels
sec.p: Figure 24 shows the vertical displacement contours of the surrounding rock under different longitudinal tunnel face offsets conditions. The results show that the face offset distance exerts a significant regulatory effect on vertical deformation of the surrounding rock. When the offset distance is 6 m (Case 1), the maximum settlement at the tunnel arch crown reaches 1.65 cm, and the maximum uplift at the inverted arch is 0.97 cm. As the distance increases to 12 m (Case 2), the arch crown settlement noticeably decreases to 1.23 cm, representing a reduction of 25.45%, while the inverted arch uplift remains nearly unchanged. This shows that moderately widening the distance between the twin tunnel faces helps to reduce the superimposed effects of construction-induced disturbances and improves the vertical deformation response of the surrounding rock. When the offset distance further increases to 24 m (Case 3), the arch crown settlement slightly rises to 1.28 cm, and the inverted arch uplift increases to 1.03 cm. This suggests that an excessively large offset may weaken the confinement capacity of the surrounding rock, resulting in a rebound of structural deformation.

caption.p: Vertical displacement cloud maps of surrounding rock.

list-item.p: Internal forces of the secondary lining in the front tunnel.

sec.p: Figure 25 illustrates the internal force distribution of the secondary lining in the front tunnel under different longitudinal face offset conditions. On the whole, Overall, as the offset increases, the internal force of the lining structure shows a nonlinear evolution trend of “first decrease and then increase”. Specifically, when the offset is 6 m, the maximum axial force and bending moment at the arch waist of the front tunnel are 795 kN and − 385 kN m, respectively. When the offset increases to 12 m, these values decrease to 596 kN and − 227 kN m, representing reductions of 25.03% and 41.04%, respectively. This indicates that a moderate increase in face offset effectively mitigates inter-structural disturbance and alleviates stress concentration. However, when the face offset further increases to 18 m, the axial force and bending moment of the structure rebounded to 897 kN and − 467 kN m, which increased by 50.50% and 105.72% respectively compared with the spacing of 12 m. This indicates that an excessively large face offset may weaken the overall confinement capacity of the surrounding rock, triggering stress redistribution within the structure and intensifying the stress response of local components.

caption.p: Lining internal force distribution.

sec.p: Figure 26 shows the evolution characteristics of the plastic zone in the surrounding rock under different longitudinal offsets between tunnel faces. Overall, with the increase of the distance between the left and right tunnel faces, the plastic zone of surrounding rock shows an evolution trend of “first weakening and then strengthening”. When the spacing of the tunnel face is 6 m, the plastic zone is mainly concentrated in the arch waist, lap arch shoulder and inverted arch area, and the spatial distribution is more symmetrical. As the tunnel face offset increases to 12 m (Condition 2), the overall extent of the plastic zone does not expand significantly. However, the maximum equivalent plastic strain decreases to 2.33e− 2, representing a reduction of approximately 31.18%. This indicates that a moderate increase in offset helps to mitigate structural interaction and suppress the intensity of plastic evolution. However, when the offset further increases to 18 m (Condition 3), the maximum equivalent plastic strain value increases to 3.24e− 2, which is about 39.10% higher than that of the 12 m condition. At this time, the plastic zones become more concentrated, indicating that the excessive spacing of the tunnel face may weaken the constraint coordination effect of the surrounding rock and induce a new plastic concentration zone.

caption.p: Plastic zone contour maps of surrounding rock.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This study, based on large-scale physical model tests and finite element simulations, reveals the mechanical response mechanism of double-arch tunnels without middle drift during construction, and optimizes the associated construction parameters. However, certain limitations remain, and further research is necessary.

list-item.p: This study was based on the Xinmajie Tunnel as an engineering case, where the numerical model was established and calibrated through physical tests to analyze the effects of excavation methods, advance lengths, and staggered distances on tunnel structural behavior. Due to the specific geological conditions, tunnel geometric parameters, and lining properties involved in the model, the conclusions may not be universally applicable under different conditions. Therefore, future research should clarify the quantitative relationships among staggered distance, surrounding rock mechanical properties, and lining characteristics, thereby enhancing the applicability of these findings to a wider range of projects.

In this study, the internal forces (axial force and bending moment) of the tunnel lining structure were calculated based on the Euler–Bernoulli beam theory (Eqs. 3–5). These equations are theoretically rigorous for the elastic stage. However, in the inelastic stage, they generally overestimate the internal forces. This implies that when these equations are applied for safety evaluation during the inelastic stage, the results are inherently conservative, providing an additional safety margin for the structure. Therefore, this approach can be approximately regarded as a conservative calculation method.

sec.p: In fact, these equations and their associated analytical method have been extensively applied in previous studies for the calculation and analysis of internal forces in tunnel lining structures during the nonlinear stage41,43,44, further confirming the rationality of the approach adopted in this study. Nevertheless, future research should aim to refine these equations to more accurately capture the internal force characteristics of the lining in the inelastic stage and to enhance their applicability in engineering practice.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
Based on the similar model test and finite element numerical simulation method, this paper systematically studies the deformation response of the surrounding rock, the evolution of lining force, and the development of cracks in a double-arch tunnel without a middle wall under construction-induced disturbances and additional loading. The main conclusions are as follows:
During tunnel excavation, the evolution of surrounding rock pressure exhibits a distinct staged pattern, generally following a trend of “increase‒sudden drop‒stabilization.” Meanwhile, the structural stress state gradually transforms from minor eccentric compression to a state dominated by large eccentric and compound loading, with the asymmetric disturbance response becoming increasingly pronounced.
The construction of the secondary tunnel exerts a significant impact on the structure of the front tunnel. The maximum increase in arch crown settlement of the front tunnel reaches 25.56%. The right arch shoulder, side wall, and inverted arch of the front tunnel are subjected to superimposed eccentric loads and disturbance feedback, making them the dominant zones for structural stress redistribution and initial failure. These regions are particularly prone to tension–shear coupled failure.
Under additional loading, the right arch shoulder and inverted arch of the front tunnel are the first to enter the stress concentration stage. The cracks evolution successively experienced the development path of “arch shoulder→ arch crown→ inverted arch→ side wall.” This progression exhibits a typical asymmetric, and staged failure behavior, reflecting a gradual shift of the dominant stress-bearing zones within the structure.
Reasonable construction parameters can significantly optimize the stability of tunnel structure. Under the specific working conditions, the “middle wall method (left first and right later)” combined with a smaller single-step excavation length effectively reduces both surrounding rock disturbance and structural eccentric loading. A 12 m spacing exhibited the best performance in controlling settlement and limiting the development of the plastic zone. Future research should further clarify the quantitative relationship between excavation parameters and structural stability, so as to improve the engineering applicability of research conclusions.
